p.text: Where judgment is given for the plaintiff in a proceeding on a maritime claim commenced as an action in rem against a ship or other property, the extent to which a defendant in the proceeding who has entered an appearance and is a relevant person in relation to the claim is personally liable on the judgment is not limited by the value of the ship or property.

Where judgment is given for the plaintiff in a proceeding on a maritime claim commenced as an action in rem against a ship or other property, a defendant in the proceeding who has entered an appearance and is not a relevant person in relation to the claim is not personally liable on the judgment for the payment of money in respect of the claim except so far as the judgment is for costs against that defendant.
Subsection (2) does not prevent the sale, under this Act, of a ship or other property that is under arrest in a proceeding.

English and Australian theory and practice regard proceedings in rem as merely a device to obtain personal jurisdiction over the ship owner and security out of which any judgment might be satisfied. By contrast, in America the ship is the defendant and the court will not give a personal judgment against the owner for greater than the value of the ship: see Gadsen Pty Ltd v Australian Coastal Shipping Commission [1977] 1Â NSWLR 575 at 584.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [250,235] s 32 Powers of Federal Court in relation to register

leg:heading.title: Powers of Federal Court in relation to register

p.text: In a proceeding in the Federal Court on a proprietary maritime claim, the orders that the court may make include orders of the kind that a court may make under section 59 or 59A of the Shipping Registration Act 1981
[s 32 am Act 131 of 2009 s 3 and Sch 3 item 1, effective 30 January 2012]
These orders relate to rectifying the register.
In a proceeding on a maritime claim between co-owners of a ship relating to the possession, ownership, operation or earnings of the ship, the orders that the court may make include:
orders for the settlement of accounts outstanding and unsettled; and
an order directing that the ship, or a share in the ship, be sold.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [250,245] s 34 Damages for unjustified arrest etc

p.text: Where, in relation to a proceeding commenced under this Act:
a party unreasonably and without good cause:
demands excessive security in relation to the proceeding; or
obtains the arrest of a ship or other property under this Act; or
a party or other person unreasonably and without good cause fails to give a consent required under this Act for the release from arrest of a ship or other property;

the party or person is liable in damages to a party to the proceeding, or to a person who has an interest in the ship or property, being a party or person who has suffered loss or damage as a direct result.
The jurisdiction of a court in which a proceeding was commenced under this Act extends to determining a claim arising under subsection (1) in relation to the proceeding.
Legislation cited in [250,245.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(CTH) Admiralty Act 1988 sÂ 34.

Where a ship is arrested, the legal costs of a successful defendant may be insignificant compared with the costs of having the ship lying idle. Formerly, (a) damages could be awarded if the arrest was made in bad faith or with gross negligence; (b) a plaintiff who refused to consent to the release of a caveat was liable for all costs and damages occasioned thereby (Admiralty RulesÂ 1952 (NSW) r 49 ); and (c) there were some provisions under the general law to regulate demands for excessive security: see ALRC, Report No 33, Civil Admiralty Jurisdiction, 1986, parasÂ 301–3. All three of these cases are now dealt with by sÂ 34 .
Where:
a proceeding in respect of a general maritime claim concerning a ship has been commenced under this Act against a surrogate ship; or
in relation to a proceeding commenced under this Act concerning a ship, a surrogate ship has been arrested;

the order in which general maritime claims against both the ships shall be paid out of the proceeds of the sale of the surrogate ship shall be determined as if all the claims were general maritime claims against the surrogate ship.
Subsection (1) applies notwithstanding any other law, including a law of a State or Territory.
Legislation cited in [250,250.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(CTH) Admiralty Rules 1988 r 73.
(CTH) Admiralty Act 1988 sÂ 35(1).

In general, the Act leaves priorities between maritime liens or claims to the common law rules. For the applicable procedure, see r 73 . For the interaction between admiralty proceedings and insolvency proceedings, see [11,867B.3] and, generally, ALRC Report No 33, Civil Admiralty Jurisdiction, 1986, para 258. However, express provision is made by sÂ 35(1) that transferred claims have the status of statutory rights in rem against a surrogate ship (and thus rank after maritime liens and mortgages directly against that ship), but the transferred claims do not have a lower priority than a statutory right in rem directly against that ship.
This section applies where:
a law other than this Act (including a law of a State or Territory) confers on a person a power to detain a ship in relation to a civil claim; and
a proceeding on the civil claim may be commenced as an action in rem against the ship.
Where the ship is under arrest under this Act, the power to detain the ship shall not be exercised.
The exercise of the power to detain the ship does not prevent the arrest of the ship under this Act.
Where a ship that has been detained under such a power is arrested under this Act, then, by force of this subsection, the detention is suspended for so long as the ship is under arrest.

Where a ship that has been detained, or would, but for subsection (2) , be liable to be detained, under such a power is arrested and sold under this Act, the civil claim is, unless the court otherwise directs, payable in priority to any claim against the ship other than the claim of a Marshal for expenses.
A proceeding may be brought under this Act on a maritime claim, or on a claim on a maritime lien or other charge, at any time before the end of:
the limitation period that would have been applicable in relation to the claim if a proceeding on the claim had been brought otherwise than under this Act; or
if no proceeding on the claim could have been so brought — a period of 3 years after the cause of action arose.

Subsection (1) does not apply if a limitation period is fixed in relation to the claim by an Act, an Imperial Act, an Act of a State or an Act or Ordinance of a Territory, including such an Act or Ordinance in its application in a part of Australia.
Where:
but for this subsection, a court would not have power to extend a limitation period in respect of a maritime claim or a claim of a particular kind on a maritime lien or other charge; and
the court has power to extend a limitation period in respect of a claim of the same kind;

then, by force of this subsection, the court has power, exercisable in the same way, and in the same kinds of circumstances, as the power referred to in paragraph (b) , to extend the period fixed by subsection (1) in respect of maritime claims, or claims on maritime liens or other charges, of a kind referred to in that subsection.

The absence of the ship or property concerned from the locality in which the court may exercise jurisdiction shall not be taken into account in relation to the exercise of the power conferred by subsection (3) .
The law relating to laches does not apply in relation to a claim brought within a period fixed by or under this section.
A proceeding under this Act commenced as an action in rem, a limitation proceeding and a proceeding under this Act that is associated with either shall be tried without a jury.
Legislation cited in [250,265.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(CTH) Admiralty Act 1988 sÂ 38.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 sÂ 85.

Although under the Admiralty RulesÂ 1952 rÂ 97 a jury trial was available on the judge's direction, trials were usually heard by a judge sitting alone: see Union Steamship Co of New Zealand Ltd v The Ship Caradale (1937) 56 CLR 277 at 281–2; 10 ALJR 467Â . Section 38 now excludes trial by jury in certain cases. In other cases, the general law as to use of juries applies: see Supreme Court Act 1970 sÂ 85 .

Subject to any Proclamation made under subsection 11(2) , where a court of a State is invested with jurisdiction in relation to a proceeding commenced as an action in rem, or such jurisdiction is conferred on a court of a Territory, by or under this Act, then:
in the case of a court of a State — the court is invested with the jurisdiction within the limits of the jurisdiction of that court as to the amount claimed and as to remedies, but not otherwise; and

in the case of a court of a Territory — the jurisdiction is conferred on the court only so far as the Constitution permits and within the limits of the jurisdiction of that court as to the amount claimed, as to locality and as to remedies, but not otherwise.

Where a court of a State is invested with jurisdiction in relation to a proceeding commenced under section 9 or such jurisdiction is conferred on a court of a Territory, the jurisdiction is invested or conferred within the limits of the jurisdiction of the court concerned and, in the case of a court of a Territory, only so far as the Constitution permits.
Section 15c of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 does not apply in relation to proceedings to which this section applies.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [250,275] s 40 Courts to act in aid of each other

leg:heading.title: Courts to act in aid of each other

p.text: All courts having jurisdiction under this Act, the judges of those courts and the officers of or under the control of those courts shall severally act in aid of, and be auxiliary to, each other in all matters arising under this Act.
For example, a marshal of one court may assist by serving or arresting a ship under an action commenced in a court of another state or territory.

The Governor-General may make Rules, not inconsistent with this Act, making provision in relation to the practice and procedure to be followed in courts exercising jurisdiction under this Act and matters incidental to such practice and procedure.
In particular, the rules may make provision in relation to:
pleading;
parties;
appearance;
the service and execution of process;
bail;
caveats against arrest or release of ships and other property;
the arrest, custody and sale of ships and other property;
the furnishing of security;
the forms to be used;
records and registers and inspections of those records and registers;
limitation proceedings, including:
the parties to those proceedings; and
the operation of determinations made in those proceedings;
evidence; and
enforcement and satisfaction of judgments of courts in matters under this Act.
The Rules may prescribe penalties for offences against the Rules not exceeding:
if the defendant is a natural person — a fine of $1000; or
if the defendant is a corporation — a fine of $5000.

Jurisdiction is conferred on the Federal Court, the Federal Circuit Court and on the courts of the Territories, and the courts of the States are invested with federal jurisdiction, in respect of matters arising under the Rules.
[subs (4) am Act 23 of 2006 sÂ 3 and Sch 3 effective 4 May 2006 ; Act 13 of 2013 s 3 and Sch 2 itemÂ 1, effective 12 April 2013]
[subs (5) rep Act 46 of 2011 s 3 and Sch 2 itemÂ 35, effective 27 December 2011]

The Attorney-General shall constitute a committee consisting of not more than 7 persons to advise the Attorney-General with respect to the Rules and shall appoint a member of the committee to preside at meetings of the committee.
The members of the committee shall include a Judge of the Supreme Court of a State or Territory and a Judge of the Federal Court.
Subject to the directions, if any, of the Attorney-General, the procedure of the committee shall be as the committee determines.
The Governor-General may make regulations, not inconsistent with this Act, prescribing all matters:
required or permitted by this Act to be prescribed; or
necessary or convenient to be prescribed for carrying out or giving effect to this Act.
